All the amazing photos, even the words used for the new Philippine tourism campaign were sourced from real travelers’ posts - with permissions of course, and the DOT’s deepest thanks. So jump in too!
All information is from Its more fun in the philippines website
https://www.itsmorefuninthephilippines.co.uk/

The Northern Luzon cities of Laoag and Vigan together with the remote archipelagic province of Batanes lie largely off-the-beaten-track when it comes to international tourism. These destinations are mainly accessible by land travel on winding paved roads with picturesque views, especially in the mountain regions, or in the case of Batanes, by air. These volcanic islands and heritage cities in Northern Luzon are all the more worth exploring for their relatively under-the-radar nature. The Batanes Islands, accessible only by air from Manila and seasonally from Clark International Airport, radiate tranquil, unspoilt beauty and sustainability: think white-sand beaches overlooked by lighthouses against a backdrop of rolling hills.
At the southernmost end of Luzon island, the Bicol region has six provinces composed of Camarines Norte, Camarines Sur, Albay, Sorsogon, Catanduanes and Masbate.

Boracay covers only 10km², including farming land and preserved forest. Its main White and Bulabog beaches are on opposite sides of the island’s central area, the narrowest point of which measures just 1km. Once well-known as a party island, this is now a laidback getaway destination perfect for everyone from couples to families.

Most visitors to Calabarzon head for Batangas province with its heritage towns and world-class dive sites: highlights are the world’s smallest volcano, Taal, the Fortune Island with its beach houses, and hiking up Mount Pico de Loro and Mount Batulao. Also popular is inland Laguna province with its hot springs and historic towns. In Quezon, the Borawan and Cagbalete islands promise a perfect tropical getaway. A must-see in Quezon is the Villa Escudero working coconut plantation and resort. The city of Lucena attracts visitors with a mix of religious monuments and natural attractions including a botanical garden and a country farm. The province of Cavite is one of the country’s fastest-growing, centred on the popular holiday town of Tagaytay and offering day trips to the peaceful Corregidor Island with its gorgeous beaches and hiking destinations. Its city of Dasmariñas is popular both in itself (don’t miss scenic Daño Street with its holiday bazaars, and the Promenade Des Dasmariñas urban garden park) and as a stopover en route from Metro Manila to Tagaytay and Batangas, and from western Cavite to Laguna. Lastly, Rizal with its capital Antipolo City (a popular pilgrimage site for the Virgin of Antipolo in its cathedral) is best visited for the Masungi Georeserve conservation area with its caves and its panoramic viewing platform with suspended netting above the karst, and for Mount Daraitan and the Tinipak River with their sunset views, rapids and cave swimming.

Neighbouring island-provinces Cebu and Bohol are the most accessible destinations in the glorious Central Visayas region, with the greatest choice of things to see and do. But they also serve as hopping points to thousands of spectacular smaller islands within their provinces and the rest of the region. Cebu City – a smaller, more relaxed version of Manila – has the benefit of direct international flights. The Philippines’ oldest city and first capital, it’s also chock-a-block with 16th-century Spanish colonial relics. Ferries from Cebu City take you to Bohol Island in two hours.

The country’s only land-locked region is also one of its most lightly populated areas, across its six provinces of Abra, Apayao, Benguet, Ifugao, Kalinga and Mountain Province. It’s not the easiest of regions to get around due to its isolated communities and terrain of mainly steep slopes and mountain ranges. This is also a fascinating region from a cultural point of view thanks to several fascinating burial sites and to the presence of tribes maintaining their traditional ways of life.

Mindanao’s capital – and the country’s third most populous city – vibrant Davao City has plenty of cultural, foodie delights and beaches just waiting to be discovered before you head to the island-province of Camiguin. As well as its tropical beaches, the latter is best known for its Mount Hibok-Hibok Protected Landscape of interior forest reserves (designated an ASEAN Heritage Park) and for its three National Cultural Treasures. Davao City’s Francisco Bangoy International Airport has flights from Singapore, Hong Kong, Doha and Quanzhou, as well as internal flights. Other domestic flights operate to and between several airports within Mindanao including the island paradise of Siargao.

This province is a mecca for outdoor activities, including hiking and diving. The island of Sicogon in the north, accessible by bus and then boat from Iloilo City, is being developed as an eco-destination. Iloilo City is also the access point to the beach paradise of Guimaras with its water sports and boat hopping to outlying islands.

Discover exotic Kalanggaman Island and nature-based activities including mountain trekking, birding and glamping in the region’s protected landscapes and seascapes. Expect world-class white-sand beaches and water sports such as diving and surfing, as well as other outdoors fun including mountain trekking.

Metro Manila is one of Asia’s premier regions composed of 16 cities and 1 municipality, with major central business districts in the capital Manila, Makati, Quezon City, Parañaque, Pasay, Muntinlupa and Taguig City with its Bonifacio Global City dubbed the Metro’s lifestyle hub. Blending charming Spanish colonial architecture, world-class museums and galleries and the world’s oldest Chinatown with some of the biggest and best shopping malls on Earth. The vibrant bay side Filipino capital Manila is also a foodie paradise that was much revered by celebrity chef, author and travel documentarian Anthony Bourdain.

Palawan’s best-known spots are El Nido and Coron with their spectacular dive sites, but there are also more off-the-beaten-track locations such as Port Barton, Taytay, Roxas, Brooke’s Point and San Vicente to discover, with their promise of authentic food and local experiences including wildlife sanctuary visits. Meanwhile, the capital Puerto Princesa City is a great place to soak up some history at the Immaculate Conception Cathedral and WWI site Plaza Cuartel, as well as to shop and eat.

Siargao’s focal point for visitors is General Luna (GL), while the island’s main town, Dapa Town, has grocery shops, a pharmacy, restaurants and cafés. Outside these, the island remains largely untouched by tourism. Perfect for those that love kayaking, paddleboarding, cliff jumping, cave swimming, island hopping and plenty more besides with lots of eco-friendly accommodation.
THINGS TO DO IN BATANES, LAOAG AND VIGAN
THINGS TO DO IN BICOL
THINGS TO DO IN BORACAY
THINGS TO DO IN CALABARZON
THINGS TO DO IN CEBU AND BOHOL
THINGS TO DO IN CORDILLERAS
THINGS TO DO IN DAVAO AND CAMIGUIN
THINGS TO DO IN ILOILO AND NEGROS
THINGS TO DO IN LEYTE AND SAMAR
THINGS TO DO IN METRO MANILA
THINGS TO DO IN PALAWAN
THINGS TO DO IN SIARGAO
1. CYCLE, SWIM AND HIKE
1. WHALE SHARKS
1. SNORKEL AND SCUBA
1. SCUBA DIVING
1. SCUBA DIVE
1. RICE TERRACES
1. MOUNT APO AND MOUNT HAMIGUITAN
1. MIAG-AO CHURCH
1. COASTAL DRIVE
1. WALLED CITY OF INTRAMUROS
1. TUBBATAHA REEFS NATURAL PARK
1. SURFING
In Batanes, hire a bike to discover Basco lighthouse, trek in the Naidi and Vayang rolling hills, hike Mount Iraya and swim in the Homoron Blue Lagoon Cave.
See and snorkel near whale sharks in Donsol in Sorsogon.
Snorkel or scuba dive – boats can take you out to walls, wrecks and drift dives.
Go scuba diving and snorkelling in Anilao
Scuba dive and explore the underwater gardens of Moalboal, Malapascua Island and Balicasag Island.
Walk through the rice terraces in the provinces of Ifugao (Mayoyao, Hungduan, Kiangan), Mountain Province, Kalinga and other provinces.
Trek to the top of Mount Apo in Davao province – the Philippines’ highest peak, at 3,144m, or the UNESCO listed Mount Hamiguitan (1,620m).
Tour the UNESCO-listed Miag-ao Church in Miag-ao 45mins from Iloilo City.
Drive the scenic coastal highways of Leyte and Samar
Tour the Walled City of Intramuros (the colonial walled city) by horse-drawn carriage or eco-friendly bamboo bicycle.
Dive in the Tubbataha Reefs Natural Park, named one of the world’s best dive sites by CNN Travel, and explore the dive sites of El Nido, including Dilumacad’s underwater cavern and Bacuit Bay.
Grab a board. For beginners, there’s Jacking Horse with its many surf schools; for pros, the thick, hollow ‘barrels’ at Cloud 9 have earnt it a place among the world’s top 10 waves.
2. BOAT RIDE TO ITBAYAT’S TORONGAN CAVE
2. SNORKELLING
2. KITEBOARDING AND WINDSURFING
2. DISCOVER THE RESORT CITY OF TAGAYTAY
2. KAWASAN FALLS
2. MT. TIMBAK TO SEE FIRE MUMMIES
2. D’ BONE COLLECTOR NATURAL HISTORY MUSEUM
2. MUSEO ILOILO
2. KALANGGAMAN ISLAND
2. STREET FOOD
2. IWAHIG ECOTOURISM AND WILDLIFE PARK
2. SUNRISE AND SUNSETS
From Batan Island take a local faluwa boat ride to Sabtang or Itbayat Island; head for Sabtang’s Nakabuang (‘White’) Beach with its famous rock arch or explore Itbayat’s Torongan Cave.
Go island-hopping and snorkelling around Caramoan and its islands in the east of Bicol.
Try eco-friendly, non-motorised water sports including kiteboarding and windsurfing.

Enjoy the resort city of Tagaytay with its mild climate, tasty mushroom burgers, tropical fruits, world-class golf courses, and health and wellness treats, especially at the Nurture Wellness Village, a resort offering a distinctly Filipino-branded spa menu
Go cliff diving, canyoneering or swimming at Kawasan Falls, 40mins from Moalboal.
Hike up Mt Timbak to see the unique Fire Mummies in their natural caves.
Explore Davao City including the D’ Bone Collector natural history museum.
In Iloilo City, visit the Museo Iloilo, the Nelly Garden heritage mansion and Jaro Cathedral, and wander along the lloilo River Esplanade.
Discover Kalanggaman Island in Palompon, a remote model of sustainability, or head off to the tiny tropical Cuatro Islas

Sample the city’s famous street food at venues including Shipyard in Malate, discover the authentic hole-in-the-wall restaurants of Binondo Chinatown, or go on a food and pub crawl of the trendy Poblacion neighbourhood in Makati. Another foodie hotspot is the Mercato Centrale in BGC, Taguig.
Kayak under the stars in Iwahig Ecotourism and Wildlife Park, and visit Iwahig’s rehabilitation ‘prison without walls.’
Alternatively, admire the action – and watch the sun rise or set, or stargaze – from Cloud 9 boardwalk with its viewing area
3. EXPLORE VIGAN
3. SURFING
3. HIKING
3. BATANGAS’ BEACH
3. CHOCOLATE HILLS
3. TREK THE MOUNTAINS
3. DAVAO CROCODILE PARK AND ZOO
3. GARIN FARM
3. MACARTHUR LANDING MEMORIAL
3. SUNSET VIEW
3. PUERTO PRINCESA SUBTERRANEAN RIVER
3. ISLAND HOPPING
Wander or ride a horse-drawn cart around the cobblestoned colonial city of Vigan with its cathedral, fountain light shows and street-food stalls.
Surf on Catanduanes Island and swim in its waterfalls and lagoons.
Go hiking in Boracay’s hills.
Frolic on Batangas’ famous stretch of white sand beach and travel back in time at Taal Heritage Village and marvel at the well-preserved ancestral houses
Soak in the iconic sight of Bohol Island’s cone-shaped Chocolate Hills.
Trek up Mt Pulag, Mt Ugo and Mt Ulap in Benguet for views down over a ‘sea of clouds’.
Visit Davao Crocodile Park and Zoo with its wildlife shows and educational exhibits.
Venture to the pilgrimage, agricultural and leisure site of Garin Farm an hour from the city.
Dig into history at the MacArthur Landing Memorial National Park at Red Beach, Palo, on Leyte, where the US general came ashore in WWII.
Stroll the waterfront Baywalk for its sunset views over Manila Bay and openair cafés and food stalls.
Cruise down the Puerto Princesa Subterranean River.
Go island-hopping to Guyam, Daku and Naked Island.
4. LAOAG CATHEDRAL
4. VISIT A VOLCANO
4. PARASAILING
4. POLILLO AND CAGBALETE
4. TARSIER SANCTUARY
4. LUMIANG BURIAL CAVE
4. BLUE WATER CAVE
4. BUCARI PINE FOREST AND NADSADJAN FALLS
4. MAHAGNAO VOLCANO
4. DISCOVER OLD MANILA
4. ISLAND HOPPING
4. SUGBA LAGOON
Discover Laoag Cathedral and enjoy cultural immersion in traditional crafts such as pottery (damili) making, ‘abel’ loom weaving, ‘basi’ (sugar cane) wine-making and ‘sukang Iloko’ vinegar-making.
Take an escorted tour by ATV to the active volcano Mount Mayon.
Take to the air with a spot of parasailing.
Head for the pristine islands of Polillo and Cagbalete off Quezon’s Pacific coast
See conservation in action at Bohol’s Philippine Tarsier Sanctuary – one of the few places where these nocturnal creatures thrive in a natural habitat.
See centuries-old coffins in Lumiang Burial Cave then spelunk in nearby Sumanguing Cave.
Between Davao and the Cagayan de Oro, swim in Blue Water Cave in Bukidnon, and rappel, climb and spelunk nearby.
Hike in Bucari Pine Forest in Leon and Nadsadjan Falls in Igbaras, both 90mins from Iloilo City.
Head to Mahagnao Volcano Natural Park in Burauen and La Paz, Leyte, with craters, hot springs and lakes.
Take a Pasig River tour or Manila Bay cruise for a different view of Old Manila and Makati.
Go island-hopping and snorkelling in Honda Bay, discovering Starfish Island and others.
Head for mountain-rimmed Sugba Lagoon, where you’ll find a floating hut with a diving board plus SUP paddleboard and wooden raft hire.
5. SAND DUNES
5. EXPLORE LEGAZPI
5. HELICOPTER TOUR
5. HINULUGAN TAKTAK WATERFALLS
5. LOBOC RIVER
5. ECHO VALLEY
5. WHITE-WATER RAFTING
5. KULIATAN MARINE SANCTUARY
5. LAKE DANAO
5. FOAM RIZAL PARK
5. WRECK-DIVING
5. CLIFF JUMPING
Take a rollercoaster-style ride over the sand dunes of La Paz near Laoag City or for more of an adrenaline rush take a side trip and sprint to the sand dunes of Paoay.
Explore Bicol’s main city, Legazpi, with its Franciscan church, Spanish pier and Japanese tunnels.
Alternatively, see Boracay from the sky with a helicopter beach tour.
Tour mountainous Rizal province including its protected Hinulugan Taktak waterfalls
Take a relaxing cruise amidst the scenic and rustic tableau of the Loboc River.
Discover the hanging coffins suspended high on the cliffs in Echo Valley in Sagada.
Go white-water rafting in the Cagayan de Oro River with its electrifying rapids.
Snorkel or scuba dive in the Kuliatan Marine Sanctuary with its gigantic rock formations, two hours from Iloilo City.
Take a dip in the violin-shaped lake in Lake Danao Natural Park in Ormoc City and simply laze in the lush rainforest.
Roam Rizal Park (‘Luneta’) with its open-air chess, monument to national hero José Rizal and National Museum of Natural History Philippines.
Go wreck-diving off Coron or neighbouring Busuanga Island.

Go cliff jumping and explore the caves and coves of Magpupungko Rock Pools, or try the Tarzan Jump on the Maasin River. Stop by the Maasin viewpoint to see the incredible sight of the island’s coconut plantation.
6. ADMIRE THE ARCHITECTURE
6. CAGSAWA RUINS
6. LUXURY SUNSET YACHT CRUISE
6. HIKING
6. DOLPHINS IN OLANGO CHANNEL
6. BOMOD-OK FALLS
6. SURFING
6. PAWIKAN CAVE AND TANGKE SALTWATER LAGOON
6. DIVING
6. FILIPINO ART
6. TABON CAVES
6. TAYANGBAN CAVE POOLS
Admire grand Paoay Church: a fusion of local and baroque architecture.
Tour the Cagsawa Ruins – the atmospheric remnants of a 16th-century Franciscan church.
Go island-hopping around Boracay. Indulge in a luxury sunset yacht cruise.
Appreciate nature by hiking along the trails of Mount Makiling or soak in the hot springs at Los Baños or Calamba City in Laguna
Go island-hopping – whether along the Olango channel or in the Bohol Sea where playful dolphins live.
Swim in the natural pools of Bomod-ok Falls.
Surf at Dahican Beach in Davao Oriental.
From Iloilo City, sail to Isla de Gigantes to discover Pawikan Cave and the Tangke saltwater lagoon.
Go diving/snorkeling on the coral reefs around Southern Leyte’s Sogod Bay dive sites and interact with whale sharks in Pintuyan with a bonus trip to historic Limasawa Island
Soak up contemporary Filipino art and the Philippine Gold Exhibit at the Metropolitan Museum of Manila, and at 1335 Mabini Art Gallery located in Makati City.
Venture into the Tabon Caves, where some of the oldest known human inhabitants were found.
Go caving at Tayangban Cave Pools, swimming and floating by torchlight while bats flit around you.
7. WATERSPORTS AT PAGUDPUD
7. QUITINDAY UNDERGROUND RIVER
7. CLIFF DIVING AND KAYAKING
7. RAPIDS
7. SKYDIVE
7. BENCAB MUSEUM
7. DISCOVER CAMIGUIN’S HISTORY
7. ISLAND HOPPING
7. PANHULUGAN SHOW CAVE
7. SHOPPING
7. RELAX ON THE BEACH
7. TAKTAK WATERFALL

Enjoy water sports at Pagudpud’s Saud Beach, the ‘Boracay of the north’, trek to its Kabigan Falls for a cooling dip and rise the zipline across Blue Lagoon with a panoramic glide and land on the white beach, then go banana boating or jet skiing.
Take a boat-ride through the Quitinday Underground River, a natural cave system.
Head to the island of Ariel’s Point, with more cliff diving plus kayaking and bamboo rafts.
Shoot the rapids of Laguna’s Pagsanjan Falls, navigating your wooden canoe past trees and local wildlife

Discover smaller islands such as Siquijor with its rustic charm attracting mainly Europeans looking for a relaxing island life, Apo, Cabilao, Camotes and Bantayan. Enjoy the thrill of a skydive at Bantayan Island.
Tour the BenCab Museum, Baguio City, with its works by Ben Cabrera and other Filipino artists.

Explore Camiguin’s historic gems: the Old Bonbon Church ruins and Sunken Cemetery in Catarman, Guinsilibas’ Spanish-era watchtower, Old Mambajao fountain and municipal building, Santo Rosario Church in Sagay town, and 14 heritage and ancestral houses.

Discover the water sports and beach paradise of Guimaras, then go island-hopping from Guimaras to Inampulugan, Guiwanon, Panobolon, Natunga, Nadulao and other surrounding islets; don’t miss the fascinating Igang Marine Station of the Southeast Asian Fisheries Development Center.

Explore Samar Island Natural Park, the Philippines’ biggest protected terrestrial wonder, which includes the Panhulugan show cave in Sohoton Caves and Natural Bridge and the Calbiga Caves, world’s 4th biggest karst cave system
Shop ’till you drop, whether at the vast Bayfront SM Mall of Asia or the many artisan outlets.
Relax on El Nido’s beaches: Secret Beach, Nacpan, Pangalusian and Las Cabanas among them.
Journey to Taktak Waterfall, for more cliff jumping, tree jumping and exploring, and to see the sun set from Santa Monica Pier or bask in the sun at the Alegria whitesand beach.
8. HIKE TO CAPE BOJEADOR LIGHTHOUSE
8. DARAGA CHURCH
8. PLAY GOLF
8. LOCAL ART AND CULTURE
8. HISTORY AT FORT SAN PEDRO
8. BONTOC MUSEUM
8. TUASAN FALLS
8. ART DISTRICT IN BACOLOD
8. CANOE THE RAPIDS
8. ARCHITECTURE
8. CLIMBING, ZIP-LINING AND SPELUNKING
8. BUCAS GRANDE’S LAGOON

Take a tricycle ride or hike to Cape Bojeador Lighthouse, an architectural wonder with breathtaking views of the surrounding area, then proceed to Kapurpurawan rock formation for a nature-inspired hike or horseback ride.
Visit the imposing Daraga Church, set on a hilltop against a backdrop of Mayon volcano.
Play golf on the 18-hole, par 72 Graham Marsh designed fairway.
Relive the age-old tradition of embroidery in Lumban, wood carving at Paete, footwear making in Liliw and visual arts of Angono
Explore Cebu City and retrace history at Fort San Pedro, Plaza Sugbu and the Parian District.
Visit the Bontoc Museum showcasing the heritage of the region’s indigenous peoples. Admire the Ifugao woodcarvings in the Museum of Cordillera Sculpture.
Immerse yourself in nature at Tuasan Falls on Camiguin island, a lovely spot to swim.
Discover the friendly, rapidly modernising Negros Occidental capital of Bacolod, voted among the best places to live in the Philippines, with a vibrant Art District, sporting scene and museums.
Shoot the rapids of Ulot River in Paranas, Samar via a motorised dugout canoe
Explore quirky architecture ranging from the Coconut Palace (by prior booking only) to the Art Deco First United Building.
Go climbing, zip-lining, spelunking and jungle trekking at Ugong Rock located in Baranggay Tagabinet near Puerto Princesa.
Explore Bucas Grande’s lagoon with non-sting jellyfish, and do sea kayaking or cliff diving. Enjoy the water bungalow resorts in the island.
9. SURFING
9. ZIP-LINE AT LIGNON HILL NATURE PARK
9. EXPLORE KALIBO, ILOILO OR BACOLOD
9. NUVALI ECO-RESORT
9. MASAPLOD NORTE MARINE RESERVE
9. ART AND CULTURE
9. DIVING AND SNORKELLING
9. SILAY CITY
9. ROCK FORMATIONS
9. EXPOS, MUSEUMS AND CASINOS
9. LONGEST WHITE BEACH
9. PACIFICO BEACH
Surf in San Juan, La Union, the surfing capital of Northern Philippines. The best season is October through to April.
Head for Lignon Hill Nature Park with its zip-line, hiking trail and valley views.
Take an extension trip to experience the beauty and food culture of Kalibo, Iloilo, as well as Bacolod, specially during the Masskara Festival during the last week of October.
Check out Nuvali eco-resort with its mountain-bike trails, zip-line, aerial walk and more
Discover the small coastal town of Dauin, known for its snorkelling, its macrodiving in the Masaplod Norte marine reserve, and its boat trips to nearby Apo.
Take in the ethnography displays in the Saint Louis University Museum of Arts and Cultures and Museo Kordilyera at the University of the Philippines Baguio.
Dive or snorkel at sites suited to all levels, especially those around Camiguin Island.
Visit Silay City, nicknamed ‘the Paris of Negros’ for its 29 heritage houses including Balay Negrense.
See the magnificent rock formations on the island of Biri, Northern Samar
Discover Cubao Expo, an alternative village with boutiques, bars and cheap eats. Let off steam at the Upside Down Museum of Illusions, Art In Island museum and the casinos.
Visit San Vicente and explore the country’s longest white beach
Get off the beaten track at pristine Pacifico Beach with its small surf-town feel and a sprinkling of resorts and homestays. On Sundays, join in with beach clean-ups in aid of disadvantaged children.
10. ISLAND HOPPING
10. ALBAY PARK AND WILDLIFE
10. SPA AND WELLNESS
10. ANTIPOLO CATHEDRAL
10. DUMAGUETE
10. LOCAL GALLERIES
10. LUXURY FARM RESORTS
DIVE WITH WHALE SHARKS AND TURTLES
10. SURF CAMP
10. DAY TRIPS
10. MIMAROPA REGION
10. LOCAL COMMUNITY MARKET

Take a boat ride for an island-hopping escapade around the geological wonders of Governor Island, Quezon Island, Children’s Island and the rest of the 124 islands. The Hundred Islands National Park can be reached by a 9-hour bus ride from Vigan.
Relax in Albay Park and Wildlife with its bike hire, lagoon boating and fishing.
Treat yourself to a massage in one of the spas, wellness centres or beach huts.
Seek out cultural sights including Antipolo Cathedral in Rizal and Dr. Jose Rizal Museum in Laguna
Don’t miss the City of Dumaguete with its waterfront bars and restaurants and fascinating anthropology museum.

Tour Tam-awan Village – an Artists Gallery in Baguio City, which uniquely blends indigenous aesthetics and exquisite Cordilleran craftsmanship in an artist’s concept for a village adapted to its setting.
Visit Davao’s luxury farm resorts Pearl Farm and Dusit Thani Lubi Plantation.
Dive to see whale sharks, turtles and other marine life at Sipalay and Danjugan Island for its protected reefs and rich marine life.
Catch some waves in Calicoan Island, Guiuan, Eastern Samar with its surf camps.
Take a day-trip to Corregidor Island; Tagaytay Ridge, People’s Park in the Sky and Taal Volcano; or Mount Pinatubo crater lake.

Explore more of the MIMAROPA region with its scenic spots including White Island (Mindoro), Bathala Cave, Balanacan Bay and Tres Reyes Islands (Marinduque province) and Fort San Andres, Mount Guiting-Guiting and Bonbon Beach (Romblon).
Shop at LOKAL Tabo, a community market where local farmers and artisans sell their produce and crafts.
Open
Close
